direction.raw_text: . NETHERFIELD - HERTFORDSHIRE - DAY. I A vast mansion is coming to life. Maids pull dustsheets off furniture; servants open shutters. Sunshine spills into the great rooms of Netherfield. outside, a glimpse of rolling parkland.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "It is a truth universally acknowledged... Its a whirlwind of activity. Servants bustle around, sweeping and polishing, readying the house for its new occupants. The shutters of a room are opened onto the imposing gardens. A coach pulls up and, through the window, we see a young man get out. "that a single man in possession of a good fortune, must be in want of a wife" A white sheet is pulled from a spinet and obscures our vision.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LONGBOURN HOUSE - DAY. 2 Elizabeth Bennet, 20, good humoured, attractive, clearly nobody's fool, walks through a field of tall meadow grass. She is reading a novel entitled 'First Impressions'. She approaches Longbourn, a fairly run down
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: th Century house with a small moat around it. Elizabeth jumps up onto a wall and crosses the moat by walking a wooden plank duck board, a reckless trick learnt in early childhood. She walks passed the back of the house where, through an open window to the library, we see her mother and father, Mr and Mrs Bennet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My dear Mr Bennet, have you heard that Netherfield Park is let at last? We follow Elizabeth into the house, but still overhear her parents' conversation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you not want to know who has taken it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As you wish to tell me, I doubt I have any choice in the matter...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LONGBOURN - CONTINUOUS. As Elizabeth walks through the hallway, we hear the sound of piano scales plodding through the afternoon. She walks down the entrance hall past the room where Mary, 18, the bluestocking of the family, is practising, and finds Kitty, 16, the second youngest, and Lydia, 15, the precocious baby of the family, are listening at the door to the library.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Have you heard? A Mr Bingley, a young man from the North of England, has come down on Monday in a chaise and four.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With five thousand a year! Jane, (the eldest, most beautiful and most charmingly naive of the girls), joins them at the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goodness!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - and he's single to be sure!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Mr Bennet is trying to ignore Mrs Bennet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What a fine thing for our girls!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bow can it affect them?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My dear Mr Bennet, how can you be so tiresome! You know that he must marry one of them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, so that is his design in settling here? Mr Bennet takes a book from his table and walks out of the library into the corridor where the girls are gathered, Mrs Bennet following.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CORRIDOR - LONGBOURN - THE SAME. Mr Bennet walks through the girls to the drawing room pursued by Mrs Bennet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - So you must go and visit him at once.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DRAWING ROOM - LONGBOURN - THE SAME. 5 Mr Bennet walks to the bookshelf to replace the book he is carrying. Mary is there practising the piano. The girls come in to listen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, yes, Papa.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please, Papa!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is no need, for I already have. The piano stops. A frozen silence. They all stare.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: when?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a How can you tease me, Mr Bennet. You have no compassion for my poor nerves?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You mistake me, my dear. I have a high respect for them; they are my constant companions these twenty years.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is he amiable?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is he handsome?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's sure to be handsome.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With five thousand a year, it would not matter if he had a big pink face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I will give my hearty consent to his marrying whichever of the girls he chooses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So will he come to the ball tomorrow?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I believe so. Lydia and Kitty shriek with excitement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have to have your spotted muslin, please!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I need it!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - if you do, I'll lend you my green slippers. Mr Bennet winks at Elizabeth and turns to Mary, a serious, somewhat pedantic young woman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And what do you say, Mary? Are you not excited by the prospect of a ball?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Society has claims on us all, Papa. As long as I have my mornings to myself, I consider an interval of recreation and a amusement as quite desirable. Elizabeth laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . ASSEMBLY ROOMS -- MERYTON VILLAGE - NIGHT. The local subscription dance is in full swing. It's a rough-and-ready, though enthusiastic affair...yeoman farmers, small-time squires with their ruddy-cheeked daughters. Lydia and Kitty, with their mother, are fussing over their clothes - straightening their dresses, tidying their hair and so on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (fussing over her dress) I literally can't breathe its so tight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My toes hurt. Elizabeth and Jane are a little apart from their family. Jane looks breathtaking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a Well, if every man in this room does not end the evening completely in love with you then I am no judge of beauty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Or men.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, they are far too easy to judge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They are not all bad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Humourless poppycocks, in my limited experience.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One of these days, Lizzie, someone will catch your eye and then you'll have to watch your tongue.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And eat my hat. She stops speaking. And stares. A dazzling group enters the room: George Bingley, 25, a good hearted soul but a prone to bumbling embarrassment when his enthusiasms get the better of him, his sister Caroline, 23, a victim of every latest fashion, counting herself superior to most company she encounters, and finally, Mr Fitzwilliam Darcy, 27, dashing, brooding with an introversion which could be misconstrued as hauteur. They are dressed in the highest fashion. Darcy surveys the hall. He catches Elizabeth's eye. She stares, with a kind of surprised shock. Jane notices and looks at Darcy. He turns away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Luckily, you are not wearing a hat. A hush falls as the local people turn to stare. The newcomers - creatures from another world - make quite a stir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Caroline Bingley, standing next to Darcy, gazes at the somewhat provincial gathering with distaste.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We are a long way from Grosvenor Square, are we not, Mr Darcy? He does indeed look superior to the assembled company. On the dance floor a young couple, staring at the newcomers, trip over each other, stumble and burst out laughing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Mr Bingley spots Jane Bennet. For a moment he forgets himself and openly looks at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I find it very charming.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My brother is so easily pleased, is he not? Darcy does not answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Elizabeth has found her great friend Charlotte Lucas - an intelligent, sensible woman in her late twenties. They spy through the crowd.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So which of the painted peacocks is our Mr Bingley?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is on the right, and on the left is his sister.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And the person with the disagreeable expression?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That is his good friend, Mr Darcy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Poor soul.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On the contrary, he has ten thousand a year and owns half of Derbyshire.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir William Lucas, 53 a hale but unsophisticated member of the self-made gentry, takes it upon himself to introduce Mr Bingley and Mr Darcy to his daughter Charlotte and the Bennet family.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Mr Bingley) My eldest daughter you know, Mrs Bennet ...miss Jane Bennet, Elizabeth and Miss Mary Bennet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is a pleasure. I have two others but
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: they are already dancing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Delighted to make your acquaintance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And may I introduce Mr Darcy. (SIGNIFICANT LOOK)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: of Pemberley, in Derbyshire! A stiff bow from Darcy, Elizabeth smiles, Darcy does not.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Moments later. Elizabeth is standing in a small group with Jane, Bingley, Miss Bingley and Darcy. Bingley can't keep his eyes off Jane, but is frightfully at a loss in disguising his instant ardour.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How do you like it here in Hertfordshire, Mr Bingley?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (smiling at Jane shyly) Very much.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The library at Netherfield, I've heard, is one of the finest in the country.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, it fills me with guilt. He looks at Jane a little blush starts around his collar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not a good reader, you see. I like being out of doors. I mean, I can read, of COURSE - His sister steps in. as the blush threatens to engulf his ears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your library at Pemberly, Mr Darcy, is astonishingly good.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you. It is the work of many generations.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And then you have added so much to it yourself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wish I read more, but there always seems so many other things to do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's exactly what I meant. He beams at Jane.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr and Mrs Bennet stand a little apart from Elizabeth and the other young people. Lydia and Kitty bound up to them in a state of high excitement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mama! The regiment is arriving next week!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And will be here for the whole winter! Mrs Forster told us!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're going to be stationed in the village!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr Bingley'turns to Jane.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: May I have the honour? They leave, to dance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you dance Mr Darcy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not if I can help it. Elizabeth, Darcy and Miss Bingley stand in silence as they over hear the following...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: officers! Lots of officers!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How will we meet them?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's easy. You just walk up and down in front of them and drop something. Lydia pantomimes the actions for Kitty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a They pick it up. You say 'oh thank you sir' and blush prettily and then you're introduced!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have long suspected that we have two of the silliest girls in the county.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh Mr Bennet! I remember the time when I liked a red coat myself, and if a smart young colonel with six thousand a year should want one of my girls I shall not say nay to him. Mr Darcy overhears this. Profoundly embarrassed, Lizzie moves away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The dance floor. Mr Bingley is dancing with Jane. His ears blushing with thrilled embarrassment. Mrs Bennet, with a group of other mothers, watches the young couple with rather too obvious satisfaction.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That dress becomes her, does it not. 7 a Though of course my Jane needs little help from couturiers. Elizabeth wanders through the throng. She looks at Bingley and Jane ending the dance - she is coy and demure, he clearly smitten -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Darcy is joined by Bingley exhilarated by the dance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come Darcy, I must have you dance. I hate to see you standing by yourself in this stupid manner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (shakes his head) You know how I detest it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Upon my word, I've never seen so many pretty girls in my life.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are dancing with the only handsome girl in the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, she is the most beautiful creature I ever beheld, but her sister Elizabeth is very agreeable. They have stopped at the edge of the dance floor and have not seen Elizabeth and charlotte who are standing close behind them. Elizabeth smirks as she overhears their conversation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Perfectly tolerable, I dare say, but not handsome enough to tempt me. Elizabeth's smile drops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You had better return to your partner and enjoy her smiles, for you are wasting your time with me. Bingley goes off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Elizabeth and Charlotte, who have overheard Darcy and Bingley's exchange.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ignore him, Lizzie, he is such a disagreeable man it would be a misfortune to be liked by him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't worry. I would not dance with him for half of Derbyshire.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Later. Bingley politely dancing with Charlotte. As he does so, he catches sight of Jane dancing with somebody else. A look of pure longing, but he cannot dance every dance with her. Lizzie too is dancing and clocks this. Lydia and Kitty are exuberantly dancing too, laughing and chatting. Darcy stands watching, a look of infinitely superior boredom on his fine features.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bingley is standing with Jane, Elizabeth, Mrs Bennet and Darcy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your friend Miss Lucas is a most amusing young woman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a Yes! I adore her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is a pity she is not more handsome.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mama!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But Lizzie will never admit she is plain. (TO BINGLEY) Of course it's my Jane who's considered the beauty of the county.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, Mama, please!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When she was only fifteen there was a gentleman so much in love with her that I was sure he would make her an offer. However, he did write her some very pretty verses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And so ended their affection. I wonder a who first discovered the power of poetry in driving away love?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought that poetry was the food of love.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of a fine, stout love it may. Everything nourishes what is strong already. But if it is only a thin, slight sort of inclination, I'm convinced that one good sonnet will starve it away entirely. Darcy looks at Elizabeth with surprise. A glimmering of interest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So what do you recommend, to encourage affection?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh dancing, of course. Even if ones partner is barely tolerable. She gives him a dazzling smile. Darcy looks startled. He has no idea she heard him. He blushes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Elizabeth is dancing happily in a round, Jane and Bingley a are also in the same dance. At the edge of the dance floor Darcy is watching.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BEDROOM -- LONGBOURN - NIGHT. 7 Elizabeth and Jane are both tucked up in the same bed, but are too excited to sleep.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr Bingley is just what a young man ought to be. Sensible, good humoured -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (completing the list) Handsome, conveniently rich -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know perfectly well I do not believe marriage should be driven by thoughts of money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I agree entirely, only the deepest love will persuade me into matrimony, which is why I will end up an old maid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you really believe he liked me, Lizzie?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jane, he danced with you most of the night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was flattered, I must admit. I did not expect such a compliment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That is one great difference between us. Compliments always take you by surprise. Well, Mr Bingley is certainly very amiable, and I give you leave to like him. You've liked many a stupider person.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lizzie!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're a great deal too apt to like people in general, you know. All the world is good and agreeable in your eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not his friend. I still cannot believe what he said about you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr Darcy? I could more easily forgive his vanity had he not wounded mine. But no matter. I doubt we shall ever speak again. She blows out the candle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BREAKFAST ROOM - LONGBOURN - DAY. 8 Mrs Bennet presides over breakfast with an endless description of the ball. Mary is doing some needle work, whilst Lydia, Kitty and Jane blearily eat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And then he danced the third with Miss Lucas. Poor thing, it is a shame she is not more handsome. The fourth with a Miss King of little standing. And the fifth again with Jane.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a If he'd had any compassion for me he would have sprained his ankle in the first dance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, Mr Bennet! Anybody would think the girls looked forward to a grand inheritance. Elizabeth rolls her eyes at Mr Bennet, they've heard this speech many times before.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kitty, be so kind as to pass the butter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As you well know, Mr Bennet, when you die, which may in fact be very soon, our girls will be left without a roof over their head nor a penny to their name.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh Mother, please! It's ten in the morning. Mrs Hill enters the room and interrupts Mrs Bennet's a babbling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a A letter addressed to Miss Bennet, Ma'arn. From Netherfield Hall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Praise the Lord! We are saved. Mrs Hill gives the letter to Jane.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Make haste, Jane, make haste. 0 happy day!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is from Miss Bingley. Mrs Bennet is stopped in her tracks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She has invited me to dine with her. (PAUSE) Her brother will be dining out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is most unfortunate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't think he was so good looking anyway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can I take the carriage?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Certainly not my dear, you will go to Netherfield on horse back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Horseback?! Mrs Bennet leaves with a secret smile on her lips.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . COUNTRYSIDE - DAY. 9 Jane rides through the countryside, A distant rumble of thunder. She looks up...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . FIELD - DAY. 10 An open book. Plop plop! Raindrops fall on it. Drawing back, we see Lizzie walking through a field, reading. She looks up to the sky...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LONGBOURN - DAY. 11 Mrs Bennet stands at the kitchen door. A boy is delivering meat. It starts to rain. She puts out her hand, to check.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (smiles, satisfied) Ah, good... The housekeeper, Mrs Hill, who is with her, looks bemused at her mistress's reaction.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . GARDEN - DAY. 12 A louder rumble of thunder. A washerwoman hastily pulls clothes from a line...it's bucketing down heavily now...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MERYTON VILLAGE - DAY. 13 In the local.village people run for cover; shopkeepers cover up their wares... a 14 EXT. LONGBOURN - DAY. 14 Mr and Mrs Bennet look out at the pouring rain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excellent. Now she will have to stay the night. Exactly as I predicted.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good grief, woman. Your skills in the art of match-making are without question.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Though I don't think, mama, you can reasonably take credit for making it rain. Let's hope she hasn't caught her death before she gets there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NETHERFIELD - DAY. 15 A footman opens the great doors to find Jane standing there soaked. she sneezes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DRAWING ROOM - LONGBOURN - DAY. 16 a Elizabeth reads a letter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a "And my kind friends will not hear of me returning home until I am better -- but do not be alarmed excepting a sore throat, a. fever, and a headache there is nothing wrong with me." This is ridiculous.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, my dear, if your daughter does die it will be a comfort to know it was all in pursuit of Mr Bingley.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: People do not die of colds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Though she might well perish with the shame of having such a mother. Mr Bennet laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am going to Netherfield at once.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nonsense, the horse is with Jane. And the girls took the carriage to town.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then I will walk there. We should not leave Jane alone in her condition.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Walk! You will not be fit to be seen by the time you get there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why the devil not. We could have them all laid up at Netherfield Hall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I will be fit for Jane which is all I care about.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . COUNTRYSIDE - DAY. 17 Elizabeth strides across vast muddy fields, slipping as she goes. Netherfield is in view on the horizon. She stops to take it in, then carries on down an even more muddy track.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NETHERFIELD -- BREAKFAST ROOM - DAY. A In the large grand dining room Caroline Bingley and Darcy are eating breakfast.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Its very formal, in fact frigid, compared to the volatile Bennet household. Darcy is reading the a newspaper; Caroline Bingley is reading a letter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (puts down the letter) Apparently, Lady Bathurst is redecorating her ballroom in the French style. A little unpatriotic, don't you think? Mr Darcy is about to answer when the door opens. A footman appears, his face rigid with disapproval.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Miss Elizabeth Bennet. Lizzie comes in, her face flushed, her skirt covered in mud. She looks ravishing. Darcy stares at her, then quickly rises to his feet. Caroline Bingley, astonished, looks her up and down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good Lord, Miss Bennet. Have you walked here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm so sorry. How is my sister?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's upstairs. (TO FOOTMAN) Show Miss Bennet the way, Alfred. Lizzie leaves. A beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goodness, did you see her petticoat? Six inches deep in mud! No response.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And her hair, so blowsy and untidy!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think her concern for her sister does her credit. A little pause, Caroline recovers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh yes, its shocking to have a bad cold. I dislike excessively being ill myself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . a 19 INT. NETHERFIELD LANDING - DAY. I Elizabeth is taken upstairs. Bingley, looking tense, waits outside her sister's room. His face lights up when he sees her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Miss Elizabeth! Oh I'm so glad to see you A doctor comes out of Jane's room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How is she?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A violent cold, but we shall get the better of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NETHERFIELD - JANE'S BEDROOM - DAY. 20 Elizabeth goes into the bedroom where Jane lies in bed, feverish and ill.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jane! Jane's face lights up. Elizabeth kisses her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lizzie! Oh, your face is so cold. They're being so kind to me, I feel such a terrible imposition.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't worry. I don't know who is more pleased at your being here, Mama or Mr Bingley. Bingley comes in having attended to the doctor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you for tending to my sister so diligently, it seems she is in better comfort here than she would be at home.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is a pleasure, I mean not to see her so sick, of course, that's terrible. I will have a room made up for you. You must be our guest here until Jane recovers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DRAWING ROOM - NETHERFIELD -- DAY. 21 Darcy is quietly reading as Bingley paces about anxiously. Caroline berates him from the sofa.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stay!? She is a perfectly sweet girl but save being an excellent walker, there is very little to recommend her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought she showed remarkable spirit coming all this way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The eldest Miss Bennet, as you know, I hold in excessive regard and I wish her well settled. Though I do fear with her families low connections there is little chance of it. Their uncle is in trade, you know, in Cheapside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If they had uncles enough to fill all Cheapside it would not make them one jot less agreeable.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . GARDEN -- LONGBOURN - DAY. 22 Mr Bennet is overseeing the gardener who is pruning the hedge. Mrs Bennet bustles up. She looks very pleased with herself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, my dear, its all going according to plan. He's half in love with her already!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (a touch disingenuously) Who, my sweetest?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr Bingley! And he doesn't mind that she hasn't a penny, for he has enough for the two of them. Suddenly a distant trumpet sounds, dogs bark. The militia are arriving. Lydia and Kitty rush past. They are dressed up to the nines to greet the officers. Mrs Bennet's face lights up. a MRS BENNET Wait for me!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . And she's gone. Mr Bennet gazes at their departing a figures.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MERYTON VILLAGE - DAY. 23 Mrs Bennet and her two daughters rush down the street into the village. Dogs bark, children run alongside as a regiment of soldiers march through the street. Geese scatter; shopkeepers stand in their doorways. The two Bennet girls simper at the handsome young soldiers. Mrs Bennet, flushed and excited, runs panting behind them. Lydia deliberately drops her hankerchief. One of the soldiers stands on it. She is appalled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DRAWING ROOM - NETHERFIELD - EVENING. 24 Elizabeth is reading a book. Darcy is writing a letter. Bingley is sat nervously. Caroline, obviously bored, wanders the room looking for distraction. She looks over Darcy's shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You write uncommonly fast, Mr Darcy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (without looking up) a You are mistaken. I write rather slowly. Caroline Bingley lingers, annoyingly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How many letters you must have occasion to write, Mr Darcy. Letters of business too. How odious I should think them!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is fortunate, then, that they fall to my lot instead of yours.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please tell your sister that I long to see her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have already told her once, by your desire. Lizzie looks across from her book.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I do dote on her, I was quite in raptures at her beautiful little design for a table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Perhaps you will give me leave to defer your raptures till I write again. At present I have not enough room to do them justice. Mr Bingley now pacing anxiously around the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Its amazing, how young ladies have the patience to be so accomplished.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you mean, Charles?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They all paint tables, and embroider cushions and play the piano. I never heard of a young lady, but people say she is accomplished.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The word is indeed applied too liberally. I cannot boast of knowing more than half a dozen women, in all my acquaintance, that are truely accomplished. a CAROLINE BINGLEY Nor I, to be sure!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goodness! You must comprehend a great deal in the idea.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Absolutely. She must have a thorough knowledge of music, singing, drawing, dancing and the modern languages, to deserve the word. And something in her air and manner of walking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And of course she must improve her mind by extensive reading. Elizabeth closes her book.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: i am no longer surprised at your knowing only six accomplished women. I rather wonder now at your knowing any.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you so severe on your own sex?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a I never saw such a woman. She would certainly be a fearsome thing to behold. Pause. Darcy goes back to his letter. Caroline Bingley picks up a book. Pauses. Puts it down. she walks over to
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Miss Bennet, let us take a turn about the room. Lizzie, surprised, gets up. Caroline Bingley links her arm and they start walking up and down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's refreshing, is it not, after sitting so long in one attitude?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And it's a small kind of accomplishment, I suppose. Darcy meets Lizzie's eye, briefly. He goes back to his letter-writing. More walking up and down. Caroline Bingley turns to Darcy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr Darcy, will you join us?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (shakes his head) You can only have two motives, Miss Bingley, and I would interfere with either.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Lizzie, archly) What can he mean?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Our surest way of disappointing him will be to ask nothing about it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please tell us!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Either you are in each other's confidence and have secret affairs to discuss, or you are conscious that your figures appear to the greatest advantage by walking. If the first, I should get in your way. If the second, I can admire you a much better from here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . a CAROLINE BINGLEY Oh, shocking! How shall we punish him for such a speech?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We could always tease him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh no, Mr Darcy is not to be laughed at!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you too proud, Mr Darcy? And would you consider that a fault?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That I couldn't say.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For we're trying to find a fault in you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe it's that I find it hard to forgive the follies and vices of others, or their offences against myself. My good opinion, once lost, is lost forever.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a Oh dear, I cannot tease you about that. What a shame, for I dearly love to laugh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A family trait I think. Elizabeth smiles, sweetly. Miss Bingley glances at Darcy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BEDROOM -- NETHERFIELD - MORNING. 25 Elizabeth wakes up next to Jane.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . COUNTRYSIDE -- DAY. 26 Darcy gallops through the countryside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . STABLE YARD - NETHERFIELD - DAY. 27 Darcy, exhausted, rides into the stable yard. In the corner is a trough and pump. He strides up to the pump, puts his head under it and douses himself with cold water.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . a 28 INT/EXT. BEDROOM/STABLE YARD -- NETHERFIELD - THE SAME. 21 From a window Elizabeth looks out at Darcy. Darcy looks up and for a second catches Elizabeth looking down at him. She turns from the window. Jane is waking up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jane, do you think you might feel well enough to leave today?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DRAWING ROOM - NETHERFIELD - DAY. 29 The doors open. The Butler as before:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs Bennet, a Miss Bennet, a Miss Bennet and a Miss Bennet, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are we to receive every Bennet in the country? Mrs Bennet, Lydia, Mary and Kitty are introduced to Caroline, Bingley and Darcy. Elizabeth holds her breath as her mother launches into untold gaucheries.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What an excellent room you have sir. Such expensive furnishings. I hope you intend to stay here, Mr Bingley.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Absolutely I find the country very diverting. Don't you agree, Darcy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I find it perfectly adequate even if society is a little less varied than in town.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But I assure you there is quite as much going on in the country as there is in the town.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Indeed Mania, I think Mr Darcy merely meant there were not such a variety of people to be met in the country as there are in town, which you must acknowledge to be true.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . a MRS BENNET Nonsense, we dine with four and twenty families. Sir William Lucas for instance is a very agreeable man. So very genteel and easy. Elizabeth cringes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr Bingley, is it true that you have promised to hold a ball here at Netherfield?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It would be an excellent way to meet new friends. You could invite the militia.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh do hold a ball.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (trying to stop Bingley being
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kitty...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When your sister has recovered you shall name the day.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think a Ball is a perfectly irrational way to gain new acquaintance. It would be better if conversation instead of dancing were the order of the day.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Indeed much more rational but rather less like a ball.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, Mary.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Mrs Bennet) Please let me show you to Jane, you will find her quite recovered.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DRIVE -- NETHERFIELD - DAY. The Bennet's carriage awaits. The Bingley's are gathered to see the Bennet's off. Jane is radiant - in the peak of health.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to the Bingley's) Really, I don't know how to thank you. Bingley beams bashfully. He can't take his eyes off her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Really, you're welcome anytime you feel the least bit poorly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you for such stimulating company. It has been most instructive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not at all. The pleasure is all mine. Elizabeth looks at Darcy, who does not say anything. She gets in the carriage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr Darcy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Miss Bennet. They share a look as Elizabeth joins the rest of the Bennets in the carriage. The driver takes off. Bingley waves enthusiastically to Jane.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goodbye. Goodbye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CARRIAGE - LEAVING NETHERFIELD - THE SAME. 31 The family are all squeezed in rather too tightly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What a high and mighty man that Mr Darcy is, quite eaten up with pride.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MERYTON - DAY. 3 The Bennet's carriage is stopped in its tracks by the Militia who are marching en masse through town.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . a 33 INT. CARRIAGE - MERYTON - DAY. 33 Lydia cannot believe her eyes as row after row of soldiers pass by the carriage with not a few of the men looking in at the Bennet girls with some interest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't believe it, there must be a thousand of them. Leading the one troupe of Militia is Wickham a very handsome blonde officer, Lydia spots him and swoons.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to the coachman) Please, drive on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LONGBOURN - HERTFORDSHIRE - DAY. 34 As the Bennet girls come into the house, Lydia eulogizing the Militia, they meet Mr Bennet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hope, my dear, that you have ordered a good dinner today, because I have reason to expect an addition to our family A party. Mr Bennet holds up the letter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CARRIAGE - COMING THROUGH MERYTON - DAY. 35 Collins, late twenties, an overweening sychophant, nervous and unctuous in equal measure. He sits in his black garb, hunched uncomfortably as he comes through town.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) "Dear sir, the disagreement subsisting between yourself and my late father over the entail to me of the Longbourn estate, has long been a subject of much torment which I have frequently wished to heal. Having received ordination this Easter and being so fortunately distinguished by the patronage of the Right Honorable Lady Catherine de Bourgh..." Collins' voice fades out as his carriage wipes through frame revealing Elizabeth and Charlotte on their way to the butchers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a His name is Mr Collins. He's the dreaded cousin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who's to inherit?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Indeed. Everything, apparently. He may leave us our stays, but even my piano stool belongs to Mr Collins.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He can turn us out of the house as soon as he pleases.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because the estate is entailed to him and not to us poor females. A cart passes, crammed with sheep going to slaughter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HALLWAY - LONGBOURN -- DAY. 36 Mr Collins is ushered in by the manservant, Perkins. He looks around his future home with interest. Mr and Mrs Bennet greet him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr Collins, at your service. (LOOKS AROUND) What a charming house! So convenient for the local village. (looks at the furniture) And some very fine pieces, if I'm not mistaken. A beat. This is hardly tactful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They are. Jane, Lizzie and Mary enter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ah, these are your daughters, are they not?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We have some more somewhere.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I must congratulate you. I have heard much of their beauty, but in this instance fame has fallen short of the truth. A very low bow. The girls are somewhat taken aback.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DINING ROOM -- NETHERFIELD - EVENING. 37 The Bennets and Collins are seated formally for supper. Mr Collins is served some food.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What a superbly featured room and what excellent boiled potatoes. It is many years since I had such an exemplary vegetable. To which of my fair cousins should I compliment the excellence of the cooking?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr Collins, we are perfectly able to keep a cook.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excellent. I am very pleased the estate affords such a living. I am honoured to have, as my patroness, Lady Catherine de Bourg, you have heard of her, I presume? Mrs Bennet shakes her head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My small rectory abuts her estate, Rosings Park, and she often condescends to drive by my humble abode in her little phaeton and ponies. A pause. Lizzie catches her father's eye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Does she have any family?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One daughter, the heiress of Rosings and very extensive property. I have often observed to Lady Catherine, that her daughter seemed born to be a duchess for she has all the superior graces of a elevated rank. (LITTLE COUGH) (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (cont'd) .These are the kind of little delicate compliments that are always acceptable to 1i121 ladies, and which I conceive myself particularly bound to pay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How happy for you, Mr Collins, to possess the talent for flattering with delicacy. Mr Collins nods with satisfaction.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do these pleasing attentions proceed from the impulse of the moment or are they the result of previous study? Jane kicks Elizabeth under the table. Elizabeth tries not to laugh at Mr Collins' answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They arise chiefly from what is passing at the time, and though I sometimes amuse myself with arranging such little elegant compliments, I always wish to give them as unstudied an air as possible.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Believe me, no one would suspect your manners to be practised. The girls look at one another.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: After dinner I thought I might read to you all an hour or two. I have with me Fordyce's sermons which speak eloquently on this point. (TO JANE) Do you know Fordyce's sermons Miss Bennet?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CORRIDOR -- LONGBOURN - THE SAME. 38 Later; we can see the girls and Mr Bennet gathered by the fire through the doorway. Mr Collins leaves the room and takes Mrs Bennet aside to a very discrete conference, out of hearing of anyone else.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs Bennet. You do know I have been bestowed by the good grace of Lady Catherine de Bough a parsonage of no mean size. a MRS BENNET I have become aware of the fact.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a Well, it.is my avowed hope that soon I may find a mistress for it, and I have to inform you that the eldest Miss Bennet has captured my special attention. Collins looks lasciviously into the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr Collins, unfortunately it is incumbent on me to hint that the eldest Miss Bennet is - very soon to be engaged.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Engaged!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But Miss Elizabeth next to her in both age and beauty would make anyone an excellent partner. Do not you agree, Mr Collins? Mr Collins looks through the doorway at Elizabeth
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Indeed. Indeed. A very agreeable alternative.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BACK MEADOW - LONGBOURN - DAY. 39 Elizabeth and Jane are walking towards the house when, across the moat, they see Mr Collins come out of the house and advance towards them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh no! Mx Collins spots them and darts through a door in the garden wall and hurries towards the bridge to meet them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Quick! This way! She pulls Jane across the duck board spanning the moat, through the house and out the front. Mr Collins doubles back and follows them into the house. The girls are no-where to be seen. He looks around, puzzled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MERYTON VILLAGE - DAY. 40 a Elizabeth and Jane arrive in the village. Jane, forever the dutiful daughter, looks uneasy- Elizabeth is flushed and reckless. She looks behind them-
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We've lost him. They slow down to a walk. And then stop. outside the milliner's shop the incorrigible Lydia and Kitty are chatting to Wickham, the dashing young officer we spotted earlier. He is utterly gorgeous - slim, handsome, tousled hair. The perfect romantic hero.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kitty? Lydia! She and Jane join them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We just happened to be looking for some ribbon, didn't we, Kitty? (KITTY NODS) And we met Mr Wickham.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He picked up Lydia's gloves!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's a lieutenant! Wickham bows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm enchanted. Shall we all look at some ribbons together?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh yes!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MILLINER'S SHOP - DAY. 41 They come into the shop. The others go towards the counter. Wickham hangs back, and smiles a complicit, witty smile at Elizabeth. She colours.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Though I must warn you, I have very poor taste.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Only a man truly confident of himself would admit that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, it's true. My rooms in town, decorated, I thought, in the height of a fashion, have reduced grown men to tears of mirth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then why don't you change them?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And deny people such pleasure?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So you don't mind being laughed at?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not particularly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is a somewhat sterile quality, is it not, to be aware of ones importance in the world.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Especially if, like me, one has none. Elizabeth looks at him with interest. A beat. The moment is broken by Lydia coming up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lizzie, please lend me some money!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You already owe me a considerable sum, Liddy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Allow me to oblige.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No! Please - Mr Wickham! - Wickham gives Elizabeth a smile and moves away to the counter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MILLINER'S SHOP - DAY. 42 The girls emerge from the shop with Wickham.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're too generous.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know. Fivepence halfpenny!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It all adds up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll pay him back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh yes. I'll make sure of that. A They laugh. Elizabeth is really rather taken with him. They walk down the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will you be stationed here all winter, Mr Wickham?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That depends on what the French have in mind. Of course I look forward to action... (smiles at her) But on the other hand
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lizzie - look! They stop. Jane's face lights up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr Bingley ! It is indeed Bingley, riding towards them. He is accompanied by Darcy. a Bingley jumps off his horse and hurries over to Jane. His open, friendly face is filled with delight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was on my way to your house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please Mr Bingley, when are you going to give a ball?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lydia!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was just waiting until your sister was quite well.-
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She is! Elizabeth pays no attention to the following conversation, instead she is looking at Darcy who, in turn, is staring at Wickham. They both obviously recognize each other and look very uncomfortable.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - when, then?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As soon as they have made the white soup.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Be sure to invite Mr Wickham. Darcy turns and rides off without a word.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lydia, you can't just say that -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will you excuse me ladies? Mr Wickham. Enjoy the day. Elizabeth looks at Wickham, puzzled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DRAWING ROOM - THE LUCAS' HOUSE - DAY. 43 A small cards party is underway. Three tables have been set up. Elizabeth, Wickham, Jane, Lydia, Kitty, Charlotte and Sir William and Lady Lucas are present. A small number of officers and other ladies are also present. We move around the tables. Kitty is sat with Sir William and Charlotte and Mary. Jane sits at a table with Mr Collins and Lady Lucas. Lizzie sits with Lydia and two other officers. Lydia flirts outrageously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . We have asked mama if we might have new dresses for the Netherfield ball.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, white, they must be white.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: White is the only colour to be worn this season.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So I believe. Mr Collins is at a table with Lady Lucas, he glances over at Elizabeth, as he talks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - of course, when you understand that Lady Catherine de Bourgh is its proprietor you will realise what an immense compliment that is. Lady Catherine spent eight hundred pounds on a chimney-piece alone. a Wickham who has been talking to some of the other officers comes and sits beside Elizabeth, passing by Mr collins on the way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (aside to Elizabeth) Your cousin is blessed with an uncommon capacity for charm. Elizabeth laughs and plays a hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will you be attending the Netherfield ball, Mr Wickham?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hope to. (TO ELIZABETH) How long has Mr Darcy been a guest a Netherfield? Elizabeth pounces on this reference to Mr Darcy and takes her chance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: About a month. Are you acquainted with, Mr Darcy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Indeed, my fate has been very intimate with that gentleman. I have been connected with his family since infancy. Elizabeth is genuinely surprised, there is a pause while she is forced to play her hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You may well be surprised, Miss Bennet, especially given the cold manner of our intimacy this afternoon. Are you well acquainted with that gentleman?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As much as I could ever wish to be. I have spent four days in the same house as him, and I think him very disagreeable.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I cannot pretend to be sorry. Elizabeth blushes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But really I speak out of turn. Collins voice breaks the moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Miss Elizabeth, I was just saying to Sir William what appalling weather we've been having.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Elizabeth cannot believe her misfortune in Mr Collins, a but she smiles politely.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think I shall take a little air. She rises and walks through the room towards a balcony. As she passes the other tables we follow and witness snippets of their conversations.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It seems Mr Wickham has met with universal approval. Though Lizzie looks singularly pleased with him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At the moment she has more suitors than sense. Charlotte looks over at Mr Collins. Elizabeth passes Sir William's side of the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now any one for a round of bridge? Elizabeth?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Really I need to take some air. Mr Collins makes his way to join Elizabeth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr Collins?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, I am not so familiar with the game, Sir William.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Absolute nonsense. I insist that you join us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please, Mr Collins, I'd be happy if you'd
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Collins resigns himself to his fate. Elizabeth smiles and slips out into the night air.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BALCONY - THE LUCASES HOUSE - MERYTON - NIGHT. 44 Elizabeth breathes in the cold night air. She senses someone join her. She looks round to see Wickham has followed her as she had hoped.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a I hope your plans in favor of Meryton will not be affected by your difficult relations with the gentleman we were just speaking of.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh no - it is not for me to be driven away. If he wishes to avoid seeing me, he must go not I. Pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I must ask you Mr Wickham, what is the manner of your disapproval of Mr Darcy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you really want to hear? Lizzie nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He ruined me. She stares at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How so?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My father managed his estate. We grew up together, Darcy and I. His father treated me like a second son. Oh he was the kindest of men and bequeathed me the best living in his gift, for I had my heart set on joining the church. But when he died Darcy ignored his wishes and gave the living to another man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why did he do that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Out of jealousy, for his father loved me more than he loved him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How cruel! Are you sure?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And out of pride, for he considered me too lowly to be worth his consideration. A Pause. Lizzie gazes at him with horror and sympathy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . a 45 INT. BEDROOMS - LONGBOURNE - THE SAME. 45 We pan through the bedrooms as the Bennet girls prepare for the Netherfield ball. Kitty is helping Lydia into her dress, they are both wearing white.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aggghh!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Breathe in! We move to the quieter preparations of Jane and Elizabeth. This conversation has been going on for some time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - I still think there must have been a misunderstanding.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh Jane, do you never think ill of anybody?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How could Mr Darcy do such a thing? I will discover the truth from Mr Bingley at the ball this evening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If it is not true let Mr Darcy contradict it himself. But until he does, I hope never to encounter him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Poor, unfortunate Mr Wickham.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On the contrary, he is twice the man Darcy is.
direction.name: direction
