direction.raw_text: My dear, I think our guest is tired after her journey. Come on, Lizzie, let's get some tea.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a My wife encourages me to spend as much time in the garden as possible, for the sake of my health. A beat. Lizzie glances at Charlotte, who remains impassive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I plan many improvements, of course. (points to house) I intend. to throw out a bow there, and plant a lime walk. (sharp look at Lizzie) Oh yes, I flatter myself that any young lady would be happy to be the mistress of such a house. A tiny nod from Elizabeth. She understands perfectly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CHARLOTTE'S PARLOUR - HUNSFORD - DAY. 64 Lizzie and Charlotte are at last alone. They sit down, with a certain relief, in a charming little parlour that faces the front of the house. Charlotte pours out tea.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a We shall not be disturbed here, for this parlour is for my own particular use. (A BEAT) Oh Lizzie, it's such a pleasure, to run my own home! A flash of understanding between them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charlotte! Come here! Charlotte jumps up and rushes to the window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's happened?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charlotte!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Has the pig escaped? Lizzie joins her at the window. outside in the lane, Mr Collins stands, bowing, at a carriage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Its all right. Its just Lady Catherine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . They both burst out laughing. Just for a moment, the a atmosphere is eased.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell me, how are things concerning Mr Wickham? Elizabeth's face changes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have not heard from Mr Wickham since the regiment left for Brighton, but I am informed by Lydia who keeps a breast of all matters military that he does very well.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh Lizzie. we hear Mr Collins rushing back into the house, and running up the stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) Great news! Great news! He comes into the room, breathlessly excited.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a We have an invitation to visit Rosings this evening from Lady Catherine de Bourgh. Elizabeth is not overcome with enthusiasm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do not make yourself uneasy, my dear cousin, about your apparel. Just put on that which is best among your clothes and Lady Catherine will not think the worse of you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . GROUNDS OF ROSINGS - EVENING. 65 Elizabeth, Charlotte and Mr Collins walk hurriedly across the lawns towards the great house. Beyond the toparied hedges the grey building looms ominously above them. It is grand without being elegant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One of the most extraordinary sights in all Europe, is it not. The glazing alone cost upwards of twenty thousand pounds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . STAIRWAY -- ROSINGS - THE SAME. 66 Mr Collins, Charlotte and Elizabeth are led up a vast stairway which is painted with visions of hell. Elizabeth stops in front of a painting of a devil. She stares at it, It seem to speak, but she realizes the voice is Collins chiding her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (as the devil) This way!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . SALON - ROSINGS - DUSK. 67 The salon at Rosings is spectacularly grand; hideously so. Heavy furniture, rows of servants. The three guests are shown in by the footman. Again Mr Collins scrapes the floor with his bow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your Ladyship. (to the daughter) Miss de Bourg. Lady Catherine is a haughty, bossy woman. Pretty a unspeakable, really. Her daughter is a sickly, irritable- looking creature.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So you are Elizabeth Bennet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am, your ladyship.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (looking her up and down) Hmm. (indicates her daughter) This is my daughter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's very kind of you to ask us to dine, Lady Catherine. Lady Catherine ignores her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (whispers to Lizzie) The chimneypiece alone cost A400. But Lizzie doesn't hear. Darcy walks into the room. Lizzie freezes. When he sees Lizzie he, too, falters, and recovers himself. Another man (Fitzwilliam) is with him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a Mr Darcy! What are you doing here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr Darcy! (another deep bow) I had no idea we would have the honour... A stiff bow from Darcy, who looks at Mr Collins as if he's something brought in by the dog. He turns to Lizzie, trying to collect himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Miss Bennet...I'm staying here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know my nephew?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, madam, I had the pleasure of meeting him in Hertfordshire. Darcy's friend Fitzwilliam, a much more easy-going chap, introduces himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a Colonel Fitzwilliam. How do you do? He bows. Lizzie returns his smile gratefully. They move towards the dining room. Mr Collins leans towards Lizzie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know Mr Darcy is as good as engaged to Miss de Bourg?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Really? Miss Bingley will be disappointed to hear that. (looks at the girl, and whispers to charlotte) What a sickly, cross little thing! Oh yes, they should suit each other very well. Charlotte smiles back, a little fearfully. She's more intimidated by Rosings than Elizabeth is, and indeed has more at stake.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DINING ROOM - ROSINGS - NIGHT. f
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The dining room is laid for a very grand dinner -- footmen waiting, thousands of candles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Lady Catherine seats herself at the head of the table. The guests wait for their orders.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You sit there and you sit there. Mr Collins! You can't sit next to your wife! After some awkward shuffling around they all sit down. Lizzie, much to her discomfort, finds herself sitting next to Darcy. There is a pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I trust your family is in good health, Miss Bennet?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They are, thank you. (PAUSE) My eldest sister is currently in London, perhaps you happened to see her there?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I haven't been fortunate enough, no. Lizzie looks at him. He colours slightly. Lady Catherine addresses Lizzie in a loud voice, from the head of the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you play the pianoforte, Miss Bennet?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A little, ma'am, and very poorly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh. Do you draw?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, not at all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your sisters, do they draw?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That is very strange. But I suppose you had no opportunity. Your mother should have taken you to town every spring for the benefit of the masters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My mother would have no objection but my father hates London.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a Has your governess left you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We never had a governess. Mr Collins squirms in embarrassment. Darcy watches Elizabeth, keenly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No governess? Five daughters brought up at home without a governess, I never heard such a thing! Your mother must have been quite a slave to your education.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (can't help smiling at this) Not at all, Lady Catherine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mmmm. Are any of your younger sisters out?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, ma'am. All.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All! What, five out at once? Very odd! a And you only the second - the younger ones out before the elders are married! Your youngest sisters must be very young.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, my youngest is not sixteen. But I think it would be very hard on younger sisters, not to have their share of amusement because the elder is still unmarried. And to be kept back on such a motive! It would hardly encourage sisterly affection.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Upon my word, you give your opinion very decidedly for so young a person. Pray, what is your age?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With three younger sisters grown up, your Ladyship can hardly expect me to own to P C it. Lady Catherine looks astonished. Mr Collins shifts in his seat. Mr Darcy glances sharply - in fact, admiringly - at Lizzie. She's enjoying herself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DRAWING ROOM - ROSINGS -- NIGHT. 69 Dinner is over and they are drinking coffee. Darcy moves towards Elizabeth but Lady Catherine interrupts, by shouting from her seat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come, Miss Bennet, and play for us!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, I beg you -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For music is my delight. In fact there are few people in England who have more true enjoyment of music than myself, or better natural taste. If I had ever learnt, I should have been a great proficient. (INDICATES DAUGHTER) So would Anne, if her health would have allowed her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please, I told you I play poorly - a MR COLLINS (HISSES) Come come, Elizabeth, her ladyship demands it! Lizzie reluctantly sits down at the piano and starts to play. Lady Catherine takes no notice and talks loudly over the music.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How does Georgina get along, Darcy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She plays very well.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hope she practises. No excellence can be acquired without constant practice. I have told Mrs Collins this. (turns to Charlotte) Though you have no instrument of your own you are very welcome to come to Rosings and play on the piano in the housekeeper's room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, your ladyship.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a You would be in nobody's way", you know, in that part of the house. Darcy flinches at her bad manners. He moves away to the piano where Lizzie is playing - not that terribly well, it must be said. A moment passes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You mean to frighten me, Mr Darcy, by coming in all your state to hear me, but I won't be alarmed even though your sister does play so well.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am well enough acquainted with you, Miss Bennet, to know I cannot alarm you even should I wish it. A beat. They eye each other warily. Colonel Fitzwilliam joins them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What was my friend like, in Hertfordshire?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a You really care to know? The colonel nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Prepare yourself for something very dreadful. (STOPS PLAYING) The first time I saw him, at the Assembly, he danced with nobody at all - even though gentlemen were scarce and there was more than one young lady who was sitting down without a partner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I knew nobody beyond my own party.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: True, and nobody can be introduced in a ballroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fitzwilliam! Come here and talk to us!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fitzwilliam moves away. Darcy and Elizabeth are alone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I do not have the talent of conversing easily with people I have never met before.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe you should take your aunt's advice and practice. Ouch! Darcy flinches. Lizzie turns away from him and carries on playing. Darcy gazes at the curve of her neck. She plays a false note, stumbles, and grimly carries on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DRAWING ROOM - HUNSFORD - DAY. 70 Elizabeth is writing a letter in the drawing room. She starts "Dear Jane..:" The doorbell rings in the background, she thinks nothing of it and continues. The maid opens the door to the drawing room and Mr Darcy enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr Darcy! An awkward pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please, do be seated. (PAUSE) I'm afraid Mr and Mrs Collins are gone on business to the village. A pause. What on earth does Mr Darcy want? He paces up and down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is a charming house. I believe my aunt did a great deal to it when Mr Collins first arrived.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I believe so -- and she could not have bestowed her kindness on a more grateful
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Another pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr Collins seems very fortunate in his choice of wife.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is indeed lucky to have found one of the few sensible women who would have accepted him. Darcy sits down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shall I call for some tea?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. Thankyou. The sound of the front door, and voices. Darcy jumps up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good day, Miss Bennet. It's been a pleasure. He bows to her and leaves. Elizabeth sits there, bemused and intrigued.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charlotte, in the hallway, taking off her bonnet. Darcy hurries past her, with a swift bow, and leaves abruptly. Charlotte gazes after him in surprise. a Charlotte heads to the drawing room where she finds Elizabeth sitting, bemused.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What on earth have you done to poor Mr Darcy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . I have no idea.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She truly doesn't. Charlotte gives Elizabeth a look 73 71 EXT. HUNSFORD CHURCH - DAY. 71 Sunday service is over and worshippers are leaving the " church. Mr Collins, in his vestments, obeises himself to Lady Catherine, who is sweeping out with her miserable- looking daughter and downtrodden governess. Elizabeth joins Colonel Fitzwilliam. They walk down the path together.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How long do you plan to stay in Kent, Colonel?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As long as Darcy chooses. I am at his disposal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I do imagine your cousin brought you down with him chiefly to have someone to order around. I wonder he does not marry and secure a lasting convenience of that kind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She would be a lucky woman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Really?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Darcy is a most loyal companion. From what I heard, on our journey here, he recently came to the rescue of one of his friends just in time. Darcy, waylaid by various people, comes out of the church. His eyes search for Elizabeth. He sees her with Fitzwilliam and hesitates. Too late! Mr Collins steps up to him and engages him in conversation. Elizabeth stops, at the churchyard gate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What happened?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He saved the man from an imprudent marriage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who was the man?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His closest friend. Mr Bingley. A silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did Mr Darcy give you his reasons for this interference?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There were apparently strong objections to the lady.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What kind of objections? Her lack of fortune?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think it was her family that was considered unsuitable.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So he separated them?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I believe so. I know nothing else. Elizabeth grows pale. She turns to look at Darcy who is joined by his aunt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wish Mr Darcy and all his friends well in finding partners suitable to their very high standards. Good morning, Col. Fitzwilliam.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Elizabeth see that Collinses are still busy with their 76 parishioners and slips away. Darcy sees her from a distance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . ROSINGS PARK - DAY. 72 Lizzie walks across the park - anywhere, she hardly cares. She is in a turmoil of misery and fury. How could Darcy do such a terrible thing! It starts to rain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a A Grecian summer house by the lake. The rain is now bucketing down. Lizzie hurries into the summer house and sits down, heavily, on a bench. Her poor sister; Lizzie gazes in despair at the rain- lashed landscape. A man approaches, across the park. He draws nearer. It's Darcy. Elizabeth stiffens. He's hurrying towards her. Sodden, breathless, he comes into the. summer house. He is in a state of agitation - far too agitated to notice her upset face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Miss Bennet, I have struggled in vain but I can bear it no longer ... . The past months have been a torment... He pauses, unable to speak. Elizabeth stares at him in astonishment. He struggles on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I came to Rosings with the single object of seeing you...I had to see you...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a Me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a I've fought against my better judgement, my family's expectation... (PAUSE) The inferiority of your birth.. .my rank and circumstance... (STUMBLINGLY) all those things.. .but I'm willing to put them aside... and ask you to end my agony...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't understand...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I love you. Most ardently. Elizabeth stares at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please do me the honour of accepting my hand. A silence. Elizabeth struggles with the most painful confusion of feeling. Finally she recovers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir, I appreciate the struggle you have been through, and I am very sorry to have caused you pain. Believe me, it was unconsciously done. A silence. Gathering her shawl, she gets to her feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is this your reply?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you laughing at me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you rejecting me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sure that the feelings which, as you've told me, have hindered your regard, will help you in overcoming it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . A terrible silence, as this sinks in. Neither of them can a move. At last, Darcy speaks. He is very pale.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Might I ask why, with so little endeavour at civility, I am thus repulsed?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (trembling with emotion) I might as well enquire why, with so. evident a design of insulting me, you chose to tell me that you liked me against your better judgement. If I was uncivil, that was some excuse -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Believe me, I didn't mean -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But I have other reasons, you know I have!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What reasons?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you think that anything might tempt me to accept the man who has ruined, perhaps for ever, the happiness of a most beloved sister? Silence. Darcy looks as if he's been struck across the face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you deny it, Mr Darcy? That you separated a young couple who loved each other, exposing your friend to the censure of the world for caprice, and my sister to its derision for disappointed hopes, and involving them both in misery of the acutest kind?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I do not deny it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How could you do it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because I believed your sister indifferent to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a Indifferent?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a I watched them most carefully, and realized his attachment was much deeper than hers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's because she's shy!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bingley too is modest, and was persuaded that she didn't feel strongly for him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because you suggested it!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I did it for his own good.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My sister hardly shows her true feelings to me! (pause, takes a breath) I suppose you suspect that his fortune had some bearing on the matter?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No! I wouldn't do your sister the A dishonour. Though it was suggested - (STOPS)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What was?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was made perfectly clear that-an advantageous marriage... (STOPS)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did my sister give that impression?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No! An awkward pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There was, however, I have to admit... the matter of your family -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Our want of connection? Mr Bingley didn't vex himself about that!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, it was more than that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How, sir?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (pause, very uncomfortable) It pains me to say this, but it was the lack of propriety shown by your mother, your three younger sisters - even, on occasion, your father. Forgive me. Lizzie blushes. He has hit home. Darcy paces up and down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You and your sister -- I must exclude from this... Darcy stops and gazes at her. He is in turmoil. Elizabeth glares at him, in a blaze of fury and misery.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And what about Mr Wickham?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr Wickham?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What excuse can you give for your behavior to him?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You take an eager interest in that gentleman's concerns!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He told me of his misfortunes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh yes, his misfortunes have been very great indeed!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have ruined his chances, and yet treat him with sarcasm?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So this is your opinion of me! Thank you for explaining so fully. Perhaps these offences might have been overlooked, if your pride had not been hurt -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My pride?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - by my honesty in admitting scruples about our relationship. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Could you expect me to rejoice in the inferiority of your circumstances?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And those are the words of a gentleman? From the first moment I met you, your arrogance and conceit, your selfish distain of the feelings of others, made me realize that you were the last man in the world I could ever be prevailed upon to marry. Darcy recoils, as if slapped. A terrible silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Forgive me, madam, for taking up so much of your time. He leaves, abruptly. Elizabeth watches him stride away, through the rain. What has she done? She bitterly bursts into tears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HUNSFORD - DAY. 73 Elizabeth comes in soaked to the skin. Charlotte runs to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Elizabeth!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was caught somewhat off-guard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BEDROOM - HUNSFORD - THE SAME. 74 Charlotte attends to Elizabeth.who has changed and is drying her hair, a shawl around her shoulders.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shall I call the doctor?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No! Charlotte, I shall be quite all right. Please, give Lady de Bourgh my apologies. You must not keep her waiting. Mr Collins clatters up the stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (popping his head around the
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on. We shall be late!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Charlotte leaves, reluctantly, and goes downstairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Later; The sound of the front door closing. Elizabeth sits down, heavily, on the bed. She walks downstairs and enters the drawing room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DRAWING ROOM - HUNSFORD - DAY. 75 Elizabeth is in the drawing room, she looks at a book on the table. It is Fordyce's Sermons. She puts it down and walks to the mirror and stares at herself. After a moment suddenly Darcy's face appears. She freezes. They stare at each other without speaking. Finally...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I came to leave you this. He places a letter on the table behind her. Elizabeth does not turn but watches him through the mirror.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not going to renew the sentiments which were so disgusting to you, but to address the two offenses you have laid against me. I had not long been in Hertfordshire before I saw that Bingley A preferred your eldest sister. I observed my friend's behaviour attentively and I could perceive that his partiality for Miss Bennet was beyond what I have ever witnessed in him. Elizabeth cannot bring herself to look at Darcy. She stares at her own reflection as he speaks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yet when I observed your sister .1 detected no symptom of peculiar regard, and witnessed only the families coarse appetite for having their daughters married favorably. And so in London, perhaps erroneously, I persuaded him of the unfitness of the match citing your sisters coolness towards him. We zoom in on Elizabeth's reflection.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was unknowingly done and though the motives which governed me may to you appear naturally insufficient, they were done to protect a friend. As to the other a more serious matter..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . As Elizabeth turns she realises Darcy has gone. Darcy's voice carries.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.0.) (CONT'D) "My father provided for Mr Wickham a valuable living. Elizabeth tears open the envelope, her hands shaking, and reads the letter, as Darcy's voice carries on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.0.) (CONT'D) "But upon his death, however, Mr Wickham told me that he had no intention of taking orders and would I recompense him to the tune of A3000 so he could go to town and study the law. We circle Elizabeth as she reads.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.0.) (CONT'D) This I did, though by now I had some doubts about his character. These were confirmed by reports that he had sunk into a life of idleness, gambling and dissipation. The money was soon used up, whereupon he wrote demanding more money which I refused, whereupon he severed all
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Holding the letter she looks out of the window to see Darcy riding away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "But last summer he was unwillingly obtruded on my notice when he connived a relationship with my sister whom he persuaded to be in love with him and made her consent to an elopement. She was but fifteen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HUNSFORD - DAY. 76 Darcy rides off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.0.) Mr Wickham's prime objective was her inheritance of thirty thousand pounds but hope of revenging me was a strong inducement. I was lucky enough to persuade my sister of her folly. I hope this goes someway to mitigating my behaviour in your eyes. If you doubt my word please have it confirmed by my A cousin Fitzwilliam.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . a 77 INT. DRAWING ROOM -- HUNSFORD - LATER - DAY 7 Elizabeth with the letter. Charlotte walks in. Elizabeth is shaking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lizzy: Are you alright?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I do not know. I hardly know myself. Elizabeth looks at Charlotte utterly shaken.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CARRIAGE/CHEAPSIDE - DAY. 78 Elizabeth riding in a carriage through Cheapside, reading the letter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.0.) P.S. As we shall never meet again, I wish you all happiness in the future. Elizabeth looks out at the high warehouse building and the bustle of trade. For this, just now, she hates him.

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DERBYSHIRE - DAY. 84 A ravishing landscape of savage and romantic beauty - scudding clouds, mountains, wild rocky outcrops. Elizabeth is walking freely, the wind in her hair. As she nears the peak of a promontory, Mr and Mrs Gardiner are below making their way towards her. They smile at her. She strides off determined to reach the very top. When she gets there she stands with her arms outstretched, her head back laughing into the wind. The view is magnificent. She breathes deeply.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LAMBTON - DUSK. 85 An establishing shot of Lambton, a charming market town. Through the window of an inn we see Elizabeth and Mr and Mrs Gardiner at a table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . INN - LAMBTON - NIGHT. 86 O In the inn, the Gardiner's and Elizabeth are eating supper. An air of high spirits. At the next table, another amiable tourist couple are also tucking into their food.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a (indicating her husband) He's been taking the waters at Buxton. (LAUGHS) Hasn't done him a jot of good.

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We've visited Chatsworth, Dovedale,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just two miles from here. close, very close, on Lizzie's face.

direction.raw_text: I'm so glad you changed your mind. Elizabeth is alert, her eyes bright with curiosity. The parkland is wild and rocky. Deer graze; rooks wheel in the sky. A sense of freedom and liberation. As the carriage drives over the top of a hill, close on Elizabeth's face. She gasps. The Gardiners gasp. A huge, wide shot of Pemberley House. It's vast, breathtakingly beautiful, set in great boulder-strewn park lands. A mansion built of golden stone, glowing in the sunlight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . PARK - PEMBERLY - THE SAME. 89 Elizabeth walks through the magnificent grounds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Imagine being mistress of all this. It is as big as all Cheapside. Elizabeth is lost in admiration.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . PEMBERLY - DAY. 90 Elizabeth and the Gardiners are being taken on the tour by the housekeeper, Mrs Reynolds, who witters on in the background with descriptions of each room. Elizabeth is apart and we witness the exquisite house from her point of view. A book lies open, on a reading desk, Elizabeth turns it over to read the title.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Keep up. They walk through room after amazing room: a breath- taking library, an unbelievable staircase.

direction.raw_text: . PICTURE GALLERY - PEMBERLY -- DAY. 91 The huge picture gallery. Elizabeth is apart from the rest looking at the pictures she stops by a painting of Darcy. She looks at it thoughtfully but is interrupted by Mrs Reynolds and the Gardiners who are following her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is my master - Mr Darcy.

direction.raw_text: A handsome face. Lizzie, is it a true likeness of him?

direction.raw_text: Yes, yes I suppose he is. Mrs Reynolds moves the Gardiners on to another painting, but Elizabeth stays, staring at Darcy's image.

direction.raw_text: And this is his sister, Miss Georgians. She plays and sings all day long. We realize that in the distance we have heard music. Elizabeth is still gazing at the portrait of Darcy, then suddenly snaps out of her reverie, as she processes Mrs

direction.raw_text: I've known Mr Darcy since he was a boy. He was always a kind and generous person even then. Not everyone can see it, because he does not make a meal of it like a lot of young men nowadays. But he is the most sweet-tempered and kind- hearted man I have ever known.

direction.raw_text: As the Gardiners look at more paintings, Elizabeth drifts out through the open doors and onto a terrace. In the bright sunlight the view of the gardens and valley beyond is exquisite. Outside the music we heard before is louder.

direction.raw_text: . TERRACE - PEMBERLY - THE SAME. 92 Elizabeth wanders aimlessly across the terrace, being unconsciously drawn by the music. Suddenly Elizabeth recognizes the tune (perhaps it is one she has played earlier - but this time it is played exquisitely). She follows the music round a corner, intrigued as she gets a closer and closer to its source. She finally realizes she is outside the room where the music is being played.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . She steals herself a moment, but her curiosity gets the better of her and she discretely peeps in. A Through the window she sees Georgina Darcy, a beautiful fifteen year old playing the piano with great passion and fluency. She is moved by the music and listens. After sometime, then someone steps into her view but is mostly hidden by shadows in the room. He is directly behind Georgina and gently puts his hands over her eyes. Georgina stops playing and laughs uproariougly. She stands and kisses the figure, the sunlight hits his face. It is Darcy. Georgina and Darcy kiss. Elizabeth is stunned to see him there. Darcy glances up and sees Elizabeth watching him. For a moment they both stare at each other frozen with surprise. Georgina starts in fright at the figure, Elizabeth turns and runs. Darcy comes out after her.

direction.raw_text: Miss Bennet! Elizabeth stops, appallingly embarrassed. Darcy catches up with her. They both blush, deeply.

From the drawing room, the sound of a piano playing.. It's the same music Elizabeth played at Rosings, but this time played very beautifully. Elizabeth is filled with trepidation; we can almost feel her heart racing. The footman opens the double doors to reveal the magnificent drawing room. Darcy is there. So is the dreaded Miss Bingley. Seeing her, Elizabeth's polite smile falters. Darcy's sister Georgiana plays the piano. She jumps up and hurries over.

direction.raw_text: In six months I have never seen anyone so altered. How brown and coarse she has become!

Elizabeth sits up with Darcy who holds the reins, while Mr and Mrs Gardiner sit comfortably in the carriage. Mr Gardiner smiles broadly at two large fish that lie beside him.

direction.raw_text: Miss Elizabeth. She eventually gathers herself.

direction.raw_text: . COUNTRYSIDE - NIGHT. 98 The Gardiner's carriage racing through the night.

Mr Bennet stops at the threshold, gulps, then the whole room turns round to look at him and a sudden silence descends. Mr Bennet is terrified.

direction.raw_text: I am...(his voice breaks up - he clears his throat) I am looking for a Mr a Wickham.

An anonymas pair of mens boots appear climbing up the stairs. We move across the exterior wall of the building to find an open window through which Lydia and Wickham can be seen. Lydia and Wickham sit, snuggled close beside the fire in their room in a humble lodging house. They're eating a meal with relish. Giggling, Lydia feeds him a mouthful. A knock at the door. They freeze, like naughty children.

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A hundred pounds!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You will agree to this, father? The letter is passed around the other girls.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course I will agree. But how much your uncle has laid on this wretched man already is anybody's guess.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you mean, Father?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No man in his senses would marry Lydia on so slight a temptation as a hundred a year.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ah, I see.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: See what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your uncle is very generous.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you think it a large sum?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wickham's a fool if he takes her for less than ten thousand pounds. I should be sorry to think so ill of him in the very - beginning of our relationship.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ten thousand! Heaven forbid!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . a 107 INT. MR & MRS BENNET'S BEDROOM - LONGBOURN - DAY. It Close on Mrs Bennet's face as she springs out of bed. Pure triumphant joy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lydia married! And at sixteen too! Ring the bell, Kitty! I must put on my things and tell Lady Lucas! Oh to see her face! And tell the servants they will have a bowl of punch! The other Bennet's are assembled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We should thank our uncle, Mama.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And so he should help! He's much richer than us, and he hasn't got any children.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How can you talk like that? Her mother gets to her feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A daughter, married!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that all you think about?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Mrs Wickham" - how well it sounds
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't know what he's like
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now where will they live? Purvis Lodge might do. Ashworth is vacant of course, but it's too far off, I couldn't bear to have her ten miles from me -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Before you take any of these houses, Mrs Bennet, let us be clear. Into one house she will never be welcome. Mrs Bennet stares at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . a 108 INT. HALLWAY - LONGBOURN - DAY. 108 Lydia's triumphant face. The cat that's got the cream. She comes into the house with Wickham. Her mother kisses her, effusively. Mr Bennet coldly bows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - and then we passed Sarah Sims in her carriage so I took off my glove and let my hand just rest on the window frame, so she might see the ring, and then 1 bowed and smiled like anything! Kitty shrieks with envy. Lizzie moves away; she cannot bear it. Wickham catches her eye, but she ignores him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DINING ROOM - LONGBOURN - DAY. 109 They are taking their seats for dinner. Lydia moves to the head of the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jane, I take your place now, and you must go lower, for I am the married woman. She sits down and giggles at her sisters. The maid brings a in the food. Lydia holds up her hand, to display her ring to the maid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You must all go to Brighton, for that is the place to get husbands! I hope you have half my good luck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lydia!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wickham looking uncomfortable. He's talking to the stony- faced Mr Bennet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've been enlisted in a regiment in the north of England, sir. l f G MR BENNET (NODS COLDLY) I'm glad to hear of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Near Newcastle. We shall travel there next week.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a Can I come and stay with you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That is out. of the question.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lydia, rattling on to Lizzie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, Monday morning came and I was in such a fuss -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't want to hear -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - there was my aunt, preaching and talking away just as if she was reading a sermon, she was horrid unpleasant -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can't you understand why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - but I didn't hear a word because I was thinking of my dear Wickham. I longed to a know whether he would be married in his blue coat...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary turning to Wickham.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The north of England, I believe, boasts some spectacular scenery...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lydia burbling on, to a stony-faced Lizzie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - and then my uncle was called away from the church on business and I thought - who is to be our best man if he doesn't come back? Lucky he did come back or I would have had to ask Mr Darcy -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr Darcy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (claps her hand to her mouth) I forgot! I shouldn't have said a word!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr Darcy was at your wedding?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He was the one that discovered us! He knew where to find Wickham, you see. (HISSES) But don't tell anyone! He told me not to tell! Lizzie stares at her. Darcy at her wedding? Lydia turns away, to talk to the others.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . GARDEN - LONGBOURN - DAY. 110 Lydia, croquet mallet in hand, drags her new husband across the lawn. Kitty follows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, Wickham! You've got to play.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, come on! Wickham looks slightly abashed - a trapped man. What has he let himself in for? Lizzie comes into the garden, looking for her younger sister. Wickham detaches himself and comes over to her. A rueful smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hope we can be even better friends, now we're brother and sister. An attempt at a twinkling smile, but Elizabeth is now immune to his charm. She nods, briefly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hear you visited Pemberley. My dear old home.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I met Mr Darcy's sister.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you like her?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Very much. (looks at him) We found a great deal to talk about.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . A beat. Wickham looks deeply uneasy. He bows and leaves. Lizzie watches him pick up a mallet and take his turn. She can't bear it; she hurries up to Lydia and draws her aside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why was Mr Darcy there?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not supposed to tell. Lizzie abandons her pride. She takes Lydia's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please, Lydia!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because he paid for it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The wedding, Wickham's commission. Everything.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everything?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lydia! It's your turn! Lydia moves to go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: People kept saying Wickham owed them money, it was so tedious. So Darcy settled his debts but I don't really like him, do you? Lizzie pulls her back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But why did he do it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know, do I? Anyway you're not to tell because it's supposed to be our uncle who paid, and he wouldn't have a minded paying, either, because I'm his favorite.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . a She leaves. Giggles and shrieks from the croquet lawn. Elizabeth looks blank with shock.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BINGLEY'S HOUSE - MAYFAIR -- DAY. 111 Close on Darcy's grimly determined face. Drawing back, we see that he is walking down a street in Mayfair. He arrives at a house, pauses, and rings the bell. The door is opened.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr Darcy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have some business with Mr Bingley. Darcy goes inside and the door shuts. The camera cranes slowly upstairs until we can see through the first floor window and into the drawing room. Mr Darcy enters and bows to Mr Bingley. He starts to talk in earnest. Bingley looks stunned by what Darcy is relaying to him. We witness the dumbshow of Darcy confessing that he has wronged Jane Bennet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LONGBOURN - DAY. 112 IS Lydia and Wickham are leaving. Mr Bennet stands at a distance. Mrs Bennet sobs as Lydia climbs onto the carriage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Write to me often, my dear'. Wickham takes his leave of Elizabeth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please relay my affections to the Darcy's on your next acquaintance. I am sure he will be pleased to hear things have worked out so well. He joins Lydia.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (through the window) Married women never have much time for writing. My sisters may write to me! They'll have nothing else to do. The Mrs Bennet and the girls watch as the carriage drives away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh there is nothing so bad as parting with ones children! One seems so forlorn without them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That is the consequence of marrying a daughter. It must make you better satisfied that your other four are single.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MERYTON VILLAGE - DAY. 113 Elizabeth and Jane are out shopping with their mother and sisters. Their housekeeper, Mrs Hill, comes out of the butchers shop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you hear the news, madam? Mr Bingley is returning to Netherfield. A stunned silence. Lizzie glances at Jane. She blushes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr Bingley? Mrs Hill indicates a woman in the butcher's shop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs Nichols is ordering a haunch Of pork, for she expects him tomorrow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tomorrow? (RECOVERING) Not that I care about it. Mr Bingley is nothing to us and I'm sure I never want to see him again. (MOVES AWAY) No, we shall not mention a word about it. (comes back to Mrs Hill) Is it quite certain he is coming?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, madam. I believe he is alone; his sister remains in town.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Huh! Come along, girls. Their mother goes into the draper's shop. Jane pauses at the threshold.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's all right, Lizzie. I'm just glad that he comes alone, because then we shall see less of him. (BLUSHING) Not that I'm afraid of myself, but I dread other people's remarks. A brave smile. Lizzie, of course, is not convinced in the slightest. They go into the shop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LONGBOURN -- DAY. 114 Mr Bingley rides towards Longbourn, a look of slight trepidation in his eyes. Darcy now comes into view riding along side him. They cross the moat bridge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DRAWING ROOM - LONGBOURN -- DAY. 115 Mary is practising her scales. Jane and Elizabeth are sitting at their work, with their mother. Kitty rushes in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is here! He is here, he's at the door!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh my goodness! Everybody act naturally. Jane completely freezes. Everybody else goes into a fluster.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whatever you do, do not appear overbearing. Kitty looks out through a window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look. There's someone with him. Mr whats his name. The pompous one from before. Elizabeth looks through the window at Darcy, her heart leaps to her mouth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr Darcy indeed! The very insolence of
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 0 it. What does he think of coming here? Elizabeth returns to her seat and sits down, heavily. Mrs Bennet hurries over to Jane and pinches her cheeks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mama!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a (to Mary - who is still
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stop that and sit down! Find yourself some work! Oh Lord. They sit there, frozen, pretending to sew. The drawing room door opens and Mrs Hill shows in the two men. They bow. Bingley smiles warmly at Jane, who blushes. Elizabeth glances at Darcy. His face is strained. Mrs Bennet is all smiles for Bingley. She ignores Darcy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How very glad we are to see you, Mr Bingley! There are a great many changes since you went away. Miss Lucas is married and settled. And one of my own daughters too, you will have seen it in the papers though it was not put in as it ought to have been. Very short, nothing about her family.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I did hear of it, and offer my congratulations.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - but it's very hard to have my Lydia taken away from me. Mr Wickham has been transferred to Newcastle, where ever that is. Thank heaven he has some friends. Mrs Bennet shoots a frosty glance at Mr Darcy. This is more than Elizabeth can bare.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you hope to stay long in the country, Mr Bingley?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just a few weeks. For the shooting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When you have killed all your own birds, Mr Bingley, I beg you will come here and shoot as many as you please.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - Mr Bennet will be vastly happy to oblige you, and will save all the best of a the covies for you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excellent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you well, Mr Darcy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Quite well, thank you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I hope the weather stays fine, for your sport.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I return to town tomorrow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So soon?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My Jane looks well, does she not? Mr-Bingley stands up abruptly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She does indeed. Well, I must be going, I suppose. Darcy - Darcy cannot quite believe it. He gives Bingley a harsh stare, Bingley has not completed his task.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (CONT`D) It was very pleasant to see you all again. Elizabeth, Miss Jane.. Bingley can almost not bear to look Jane in the eye as he acknowledges them all very briefly and bolts for the door. Mrs Bennet fusses around him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You must come again. For when you were in town last winter you promised to take a family dinner with us. I have not forgot you see. At least three courses. Bingley and Darcy take their leave, leaving the Bennets sitting in silence all looking at once another. Kitty is fit to burst out laughing, Elizabeth and Jane horrified by the awkward visit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE LANE - NEAR LONGBOURN - THE SAME. 116 a Bingley is pacing backwards and forwards in despair muttering to himself. Darcy looks at him in extreme frustration.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh damn, damn, buggery, damn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What were you thinking of? It's as if Bingley has not heard. He keeps pacing up and down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Damn and blast, oh buggery, damn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DRAWING ROOM - LONGBOURN - DAY. 117 The girls are now spread around the room. Jane in. despair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I'm glad that's over. We can now meet as indifferent acquaintances.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh yes? Jane, take care.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You cannot think me so weak as to be in A danger now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think you are in great danger of making him as much in love with you as ever.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry, though, that he came with Mr Darcy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh Jane, I have acted so stupidly. Had I been in love, I could not have been more blind!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you mean? The door bell rings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (at the window) It is him. He's back. He's come again. a A stunned reaction.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Everyone has regained their decorous positions. They hear A Bingley's voice at the door and he comes in very awkwardly. He smiles. His face is crimson with embarrassment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: erm, I know this is all very embarrassing, but I would like to request the privilege of speaking to Miss Jane - They all look at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - alone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Girls. Everybody to the kitchen. Immediately. Oh, Mr Bingley. It is so good to see you again so soon. She ushers everyone out, not before squeezing Jane's hand. Now Jane and Bingley are alone, facing each other with extreme embarrassment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Miss Bennet, you have been the victim of a huge misunderstanding. Suffice to say, I have been an unmitigated and comprehensive ass. And therefore, I would like to ask you -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HALLWAY - LONGBOURN - THE SAME. 118 Mrs Bennet, Kitty, Mary and Mr Bennet are all jostling for a position at the door in order to overhear events inside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ssssshhh! Elizabeth is apart from her family. She cannot bear to be there. She walks down the corridor and out of the house into the garden. Through a window she sees Bingley on one knee, her eyes fill with tears as she walks away from the house. - CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DRAWING ROOM - LONGBOURN - THE SAME. 119 a Bingley looks at Jane, desperately worried. A pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a Yes. A hundred times - yes. Mrs Bennet and the girls throw open the double doors to the drawing room and come crashing in. Bingley and Jane beam at them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank the Lord for that. I thought it would never happen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . GARDEN -- LONGBOURN -- THE SAME. 120 Elizabeth is sat under a tree crying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . COUNTRYSIDE - OVER LOOKING LONGBOURN - THE SAME. 121 Darcy looks down at Longbourn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BEDROOM - LONGBOURN - NIGHT. 122 Mr Bennet and Mrs Bennet are in bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am sure they will do well together, A their tempers are much alike. They will be cheated assiduously by their servants, and be so generous with the rest, they will always exceed their income.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Exceed their income? He has five thousand a year! I knew she could not be so beautiful for nothing. The camera moves through to another bedroom - where Mary is reading a book out loud to Kitty - then to yet another
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . ELIZABETH'S BEDROOM - NIGHT. 123 Jane and Elizabeth lie in bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He has made me so happy. You know, he. was totally ignorant of my being in town last spring!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How did he account for it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He thought me indifferent!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Unfathomable.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No doubt poisoned by his pernicious sister.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bravo! That is the most unforgiving speech you've ever made.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh Lizzie, if I could but see you so happy. If there were such another man for you! There is a noise outside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Perhaps, if I have very good luck, I may meet with another Mr Collins in time. What is that? More noise, it sounds like a carriage, then a loud banging on the door downstairs. The girls look at each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DOWNSTAIRS -- LONGBOURN - NIGHT. 12.4- Mr Bennet, Mrs Bennet and the girls lit by only candles have gathered. The door bangs again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe he's changed his mind. Timidly, Mr Bennet opens the door revealing a wide-eyed Lady Catherine de Bourgh. Everyone gasps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lady Catherine! Lady Catherine does not acknowledge her, but comes in uninvited, inspecting the assembled company of aghast Bennets.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Mrs Bennet) And these are your daughters, I suppose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All but one, the youngest has been lately married your ladyship. And my eldest was only proposed to yesterday afternoon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have a very small garden, madam.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a I am sure it is nothing compared to Rosings, but it is larger than Sir William Lucas's, I can assure you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Could I offer you a cup of tea, perhaps?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Absolutely not! I must speak to Miss Elizabeth alone, as a matter of complete urgency. The Bennets all look at each other", bewildered by this strange turn of events.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DRAWING ROOM - LONGBOURN - NIGHT. 125 Elizabeth leads the way into the drawing room - lights an oil lamp. Lady Catherine walks in. The door closes behind them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can be at no loss, Miss Bennet, to understand why I am`here. a Lit only by the oil lamp Lady Catherine resembles a flickering ghoul.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Indeed you are mistaken. I can not account for this honour at all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Miss Bennet, I warn you, I am not to be trifled with. A report of a most alarming nature has reached me that you intend to be united with my nephew, Mr Darcy. Elizabeth stares at her, amazed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know this to be a scandalous falsehood, though not wishing to injure him by supposing it possible, I instantly set off to make my sentiments known.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you believed it impossible, I wonder you took the trouble of coming so far.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To hear it contradicted, Miss Bennet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your coming here will be rather a confirmation, surely, if indeed such a report exists.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If? Do you then pretend to be ignorant of it? Has it not been industriously circulated by yourself?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have never heard of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And can you declare there is no foundation for it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I do not pretend to possess equal frankness with your ladyship. You may ask the questions, which I may not choose to answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is not to be borne. Has my nephew made you an offer of marriage?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your Ladyship declared it to be impossible.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let me be understood. Mr Darcy is engaged to my daughter. Now what have you to say?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Only this - if that is the case you can have no reason to suppose he will make an offer to me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh obstinate girl! This union has been planned since their infancy. Do you think it can be prevented by a young woman of inferior birth, of no importance in the world and wholly unallied to his family? Whose own sister's elopement resulted in the scandalously patched-up marriage, only achieved at the expense of your uncle? Heaven and earth, are the shades of Pemberly to be thus polluted? Now tell me once and for all, are you engaged to him?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am not.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And will you promise never to enter into such an engagement?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I will not. And I certainly never shall. Allow me to say, the arguments which you have supported this extraordinary application have been as frivolous as the application was ill-judged. You have, insulted me in every possible method and can now have nothing further to say. I must ask you to leave immediately. Good night. Elizabeth throws open.the door, revealing the family outside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have never been thus treated in my entire life. Lady Catherine storms past the family and out into the night. Elizabeth is standing shaking with the excitement of having stood so firmly up for herself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lizzie, what on earth is going on?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just a small misunderstanding. She walks past them to bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lizzie!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For once in your life. Just leave me alone. Everyone looks aghast at Elizabeth's reaction.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BEDROOM - LONGBOURN - NIGHT. 126 Jane is fast asleep. Elizabeth unable to sleep. She quietly climbs out of bed and creeps out of the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DRAWING ROOM - LONGBOURN -- THE SAME. 127 Elizabeth sits alone downstairs, thinking. Outside we see dawn is breaking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LONGBOURN - DAWN. 128 Elizabeth creeps out into the garden and wanders around through the early morning mist, as the sun starts to rise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . COUNTRYSIDE OVERLOOKING LONGBOURN - THE SAME. 129 Elizabeth walks out into the open countryside. The mists are starting to evaporate. From out of the mist in the distance a figure emerges. Her heart misses a beat. She is alone, vulnerable. Then she sees it is Darcy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr Darcy!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you doing out here so early?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I could not sleep.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Me neither. I have been up.most of the night. A Elizabeth hardly knows how to react at this unexpected meeting. Rather politely she thanks Mr Darcy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr Darcy, I must thank you for your unexampled generosity to both my sisters. I know what kindnesses you have done for poor Lydia and suspect your hand in the happy resolution for Jane also.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am alarmed that you know of what I have been so in earnest to keep silent. But you must know that your happiness was one of my prime inducements. Elizabeth looks at Darcy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (CONT`D) I know you are too generous to trifle with me. I believe you spoke with my Aunt last night, and it has taught me to hope as I had scarcely allowed myself before. If your feelings are still what they were last April, tell me so at once. My affections and wishes are unchanged, but A one word from you will silence me forever.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Elizabeth is silent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If, however, your feelings have changed... Elizabeth gazes at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I would have to tell you, you have bewitched me body and soul and I love and love and love you. And never wish to be parted from you from this day on. Elizabeth looks at him. She does not say a word. Darcy is staring at her for a reply. A tear rolls down Elizabeth's cheek.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am very happy to inform you that not only have my sentiments changed there are no other words which could give me greater pleasure. Darcy stares at her. They both start to cry. Darcy very, very slowly and gently touches her face. She closes her eyes. They kiss. She touches his face with her hand, the kiss becomes passionate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DRAWING ROOM - LONGBOURN - DUSK. 130 The place is in an uproar. Bingley, Jane, Mary, Kitty, Mr and Mrs Bennet are all gathered, fretting terribly about Elizabeth's whereabouts. Through a window we see Elizabeth lead Darcy along the duck board plank across the moat. Elizabeth enters the house, everybody starts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lizzie, where have you been. We thought something had happened to you. Darcy follows Elizabeth in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr Darcy! What on earth are you doing here? Elizabeth takes Mr Darcy's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr Darcy has come to speak with Papa. Everyone is stunned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . a 131 INT. HALLWAY/LIBRARY - LONGBOURN - DAY. 131 Elizabeth paces outside the door of the library, waiting. After a while Darcy emerges, he gives Elizabeth the briefest of smiles and leaves the door open. Elizabeth walks in. Her father is in a state of shock.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lizzie, are you out of your senses? I thought you hated the man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, Papa.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is rich, to be sure, and you will have more fine carriages than Jane. But will that make you happy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Have you no other objection than your belief in my indifference?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: None at all. We all know him to be a proud, unpleasant sort of fellow, but this would be nothing if you really liked him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (tears in her eyes) I do like him! (WITH PASSION) I love him! He's not proud. It's I who's been prejudiced, who didn't realize ... You don't know him, Papa...if I told you what he's really like. What he's done.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What has he done?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . GARDEN -- LONGBOURN - DAY. 132 Darcy, in an agony, paces up and down the lawn. He looks at the library window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : a 133 INT. LIBRARY - LONGBOURN - DAY. 133 Mr Bennet stares at his daughter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good Lord. I must pay him back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (shakes her head) No, you mustn't tell anyone! He wouldn't want it. (PAUSE) We misjudged him, me more than anyone. In every way,not just in this matter. I've been so blind. He's been so blind! About Jane, about so many things. Then so have I... (BREATHLESS PAUSE) You see, he and I are so similiar...we're both so stubborn... (SHAKY LAUGH) Oh Papa... Mr Bennet gazes at his daughter-. He still can't quite take it in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You do love him, don't you? Elizabeth nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a Very much. He looks at her earnestly, searching her face. He loves his daughter very deeply. What he sees leaves him in no doubt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I cannot believe that anyone can deserve you, but it seems I am over-ruled. So I heartily give my consent. Elizabeth jumps up and puts her arms around him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I could not have parted with you, my Lizzie, to any one less worthy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh thank you! She starts to rush out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (calls out after her) And if any young men come for Mary or Kitty, send them in, for I am quite at a leisure.
direction.name: direction
